docs.snippet: The Roanoke gained quite a reputation by bring- ing the Japanese Ambassadors from Aspinwall to Washington. She is one of the largest steam frigates afloat, rating 44 guns.

headline.main: THE BLOCKADING SQUADRON.; DAILY ROUTINE ON A MAN-OF-WAR OFFICERS AND CREW OF THE ROANOKE THE FLEET AT FORTRESS MONROE.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Roanoke gained quite a reputation by bring- ing the Japanese Ambassadors from Aspinwall to Washington. She is one of the largest steam frigates afloat, rating 44 guns.

docs.snippet: Yesterday was a still day in Washington, and along the lines of the Army across the Potomac.

docs.snippet: Capt. ROBERT WILLIAMS, Assistant Adjutant-General, attached to Gen. BANKS' Division, has accepted the command of a regiment of Massachusetts Cavalry, six companies of which have already been raised and equipped. It is expected that he will leave...

headline.main: AFFAIRS ON THE UPPER POTOMAC.; INTERESTING REPORTS FROM THE REBELS.

docs.lead_paragraph: Capt. ROBERT WILLIAMS, Assistant Adjutant-General, attached to Gen. BANKS' Division, has accepted the command of a regiment of Massachusetts Cavalry, six companies of which have already been raised and equipped. It is expected that he will leave herein about ten days.

docs.snippet: Lieut. MAXWELL'S report of the last affair on the coast of North Carolina is as follows:

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; AFFAIRS AT THE NATIONAL CAPITAL Grand Review of Cavalry and Artillery by Gen. McClellan. A MAGNIFICENT SPECTACLE Official Report of the Expedition to Ocracoke. IMPORTANT FROM MISSOURI. Details of the Siege of Lexington. How the Rebels Succeeded in Cutting off the Supplies of Water.The National Troops obliged to Drink Vinegar. Over a Thousand Rebels Killedand Wounded. GEN. PRESNTISS COMMUNICATIONS CUT OFF SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON. DISTINGUISHED OFFICERS COMMISSIONED. THE KENTUCKY CAVALRY. AN ANCIENT PENSIONER. THE HEALTH OF THE TROOPS. REVIEW OF CAVALRY AND ARTILLERY. TREASURY NOTES. A MARRIAGE. PENSIONS TO WIDOWS. FEMALE REBELS. A DIFFICULTY. MUNITIONS SEIZED. GEN. HANCOCK'S COMMAND. DISPATCH TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS.

docs.snippet: The Cabinet has not yet decided what to do with Gen. FREMONT. The rumor that he was to come to Washington for the purpose of explaining away charges made against him by his enemies at St. Louis, has no foundation.

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; Important News from the National Capital. Further Instructions from the Secretary of State Regarding Confiscations. Secretary Seward and the Correspondent of the London Times. More Distinguished Foreign Officers inthe National Army. Curious Statement of a Deserter from Manassas. IMPORTANT NEWS FROM MISSOURI. The National Flag Floating Over Lexington on Saturday. Details of the Battle at Blue Mills Landing.The State Convention Again Called Together.Enthusiastic Reception of Ohio Troops in Kentucky. SECRETARY SEWARD AND DR. RUSSELL. POLITICAL ARRESTS. A QUIET DAY. ANOTHER REVIEW IN THE RAIN. CAVALRY FROM MICHIGAN. NO FOREIGN MAIL. CONDITION OF MR. WALKER. COL. EINSTEIN UNDER ARREST. DISTINGUISHED FOREIGN OFFICERS. RESULT OF IMPRUDENCE. DESERTERS ARRESTED. ARRESTED. THE REBELS ON SUNSON'S HILL. OFFICERS IN THE REBEL SERVICE. FLAG-RAISING

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cabinet has not yet decided what to do with Gen. FREMONT. The rumor that he was to come to Washington for the purpose of explaining away charges made against him by his enemies at St. Louis, has no foundation.

docs.snippet: The Commissioners now engaged in revising the Charter of this City lately solicited suggestions, in the line of improvement or reform, from the officials in charge of the various Bureaus of the Municipal Government.
